ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 10 hours
on average, 2-3 hours / week

Probably 45-90 minutes a week on the basic course stuff. I worked on my systematic review alone and it took a very long time. At least 15 hours the last week but smaller and more variable the preceding weeks.
About 4-5 hours/week in the beginning to read the article and write a summary of the article. A lot more the last few weeks...at least 10 hrs/week.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The content of this course was very interesting, but I thought that it was really difficult to do a systematic review without actually learning how to do one as a part of the class instruction. Luckily my partner had done one before, but without that I would have been completely lost. It is a great skill to have and I like the project a lot, but I think we needed to be taught how to do this in class if we are expected to do it.

This course provided a nice overview of maternal and child health. It is one of the only courses at YSPH to provide instruction on this topic. We covered lots of relevant material and it was great to learn from the professor's expertise in the field.
strengths: the professor (incredibly knowledgeable about the topics covered), format (good mix of lectures and student-led discussions), readings (not too much of it and focused on critical research)

Strengths: The course taught me important skills regarding analyzing available knowledge while constantly and vigilantly improving your approach to Public Health. The professor brought a lot of his work experience into the course. The class has changed the way I think. Weaknesses: It felt like there was way too much emphasis on federal guidelines as the end approach. There are many available strategies for improving nutritional status. I wish we had talked more about some contemporary issues like golden rice or how monoculture effects nutrition. This would help bring the focus to how our world is being shaped and help us engage with this issue on multiple fronts. Some countries may have had an increase in status after a major world event or change in their society. But the issues were look almost at a strictly "what should our advertisements say" or "what should this one specific government program do." These are not the only channels which affect peoples nutrition status.

Over the course of the semester you will learn a tremendous amount about maternal and child public health nutrition, as well as how to write a systematic review. Dr. Perez-Escamilla is a leader in his field and is a role model in how to conduct research that drives policy.

The course doesnt give students alot of opportunity for critical thinking or decision making, it is a good course for gaining a elementary understanding of child/maternal nutrition and policies affecting it.
Strengths: materal, layout of class Weaknesses: group projects can be difficult

Rafael is extremely interesting and knowledgable. Loved all his anecdotes and experience. He is very inspirational. I really liked the organization of the class-- articles with written weekly summaries initially. Then, at the end as we got closer to the deadline for the systematic review we could focus on that without other assignments.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Excellent teacher, just would have loved to learn how to do a systematic review from him. He was very inspiring!

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  I really enjoyed the class and Prof. Perez-Escamilla's teaching style. The professor was very knowledgeable on the class topics and provided a great overview. I really enjoyed the article discussions during the first part of the classes, however would have loved if the second part could have been a bit more interactive and discussion-based.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Rafael is a fantastic professor - he is approachable and supportive of students, knows the content in and out, does a great job tying more theoretical material to real world examples, and provides feedback himself on all assignments
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Great professor! I love the professors enthusiasm for the causes he believes in.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Rafael is a fantastic professor who has developed excellent course materials for us.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla care tremendously about his students and provides such a great example on how to conduct public health research that impacts communities and policies.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Every single lecture was an excellent learning opportunity. Thank you
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Amazing professor. Expert in the field and really knows his stuff.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  He is fantastic! Highly recommend if you have any interest in nutrition, especially child or maternal health

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would only recommend it if the systematic review is taught in class. With that, it would probably be my best class!
The course provides a nice overview of maternal/child health. I would highly recommend this course to another student.

Would highly recommend this course if you're interested in nutrition topics, especially in developing country settings. Rafael is an expert in the field and the course is well-focused on critical issues and readings.
Must-take global health course!
A very good course that will teach you many useful PH skills (particularly how to write a systematic lit review).
Amazing class if you are interested in this topic
Loved it! My favorite course of the semester. Highly recommend!
